clueweb22-en0016-82-17265.point_content: The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a dramatic loss of human life worldwide and presents an unprecedented challenge to public health, food systems and the world of work.
spans: The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a dramatic loss of human life worldwide and presents an unprecedented challenge to public health, food systems and the world of work.

clueweb22-en0016-82-17265.point_content: The economic and social disruption caused by the pandemic is devastating: tens of millions of people are at risk of falling into extreme poverty, while the number of undernourished people could increase significantly.
spans: The economic and social disruption caused by the pandemic is devastating: tens of millions of people are at risk of falling into extreme poverty, while the number of undernourished people, currently estimated at nearly 690 million, could increase by up to 132 million by the end of the year.

clueweb22-en0016-82-17265.point_content: Nearly half of the world’s 3.3 billion global workforce are at risk of losing their livelihoods, with informal economy workers being particularly vulnerable due to lack of social protection and access to healthcare.
spans: Nearly half of the world’s 3.3 billion global workforce are at risk of losing their livelihoods. Informal economy workers are particularly vulnerable because the majority lack social protection and access to quality health care and have lost access to productive assets.

clueweb22-en0016-82-17265.point_content: Without income during lockdowns, many people are unable to feed themselves and their families, leading to less food and less nutritious food.
spans: Without the means to earn an income during lockdowns, many are unable to feed themselves and their families. For most, no income means no food, or, at best, less food and less nutritious food.

clueweb22-en0016-82-17265.point_content: The pandemic has disrupted the entire food system, preventing farmers from accessing markets and agricultural workers from harvesting crops, thus disrupting food supply chains and reducing access to healthy diets.
spans: The pandemic has been affecting the entire food system and has laid bare its fragility. Border closures, trade restrictions and confinement measures have been preventing farmers from accessing markets, including for buying inputs and selling their produce, and agricultural workers from harvesting crops, thus disrupting domestic and international food supply chains and reducing access to healthy, safe and diverse diets.

clueweb22-en0016-82-17265.point_content: The pandemic has decimated jobs and placed millions of livelihoods at risk, threatening food security and nutrition especially in low-income countries and marginalized populations.
spans: The pandemic has decimated jobs and placed millions of livelihoods at risk. As breadwinners lose jobs, fall ill and die, the food security and nutrition of millions of women and men are under threat, with those in low-income countries, particularly the most marginalized populations, which include small-scale farmers and indigenous peoples, being hardest hit.

clueweb22-en0016-82-17265.point_content: Millions of agricultural workers face working poverty, malnutrition, poor health, lack of safety and labour protection, and may continue working in unsafe conditions due to low and irregular incomes.
spans: Millions of agricultural workers – waged and self-employed – while feeding the world, regularly face high levels of working poverty, malnutrition and poor health, and suffer from a lack of safety and labour protection as well as other types of abuse. With low and irregular incomes and a lack of social support, many of them are spurred to continue working, often in unsafe conditions, thus exposing themselves and their families to additional risks.

clueweb22-en0016-82-17265.point_content: Migrant agricultural workers are particularly vulnerable due to risks in transport, working and living conditions and difficulty accessing government support measures.
spans: Migrant agricultural workers are particularly vulnerable, because they face risks in their transport, working and living conditions and struggle to access support measures put in place by governments.

clueweb22-en0016-82-17265.point_content: Guaranteeing safety, health, better incomes and protection for all agri-food workers is critical to saving lives and protecting public health, livelihoods and food security.
spans: Guaranteeing the safety and health of all agri-food workers – from primary producers to those involved in food processing, transport and retail, including street food vendors – as well as better incomes and protection, will be critical to saving lives and protecting public health, people’s livelihoods and food security.

clueweb22-en0016-82-17265.point_content: In the COVID-19 crisis, food security, public health, employment and labour issues converge, requiring adherence to workplace safety and health practices and protection of labour rights.
spans: In the COVID-19 crisis food security, public health, and employment and labour issues, in particular workers’ health and safety, converge. Adhering to workplace safety and health practices and ensuring access to decent work and the protection of labour rights in all industries will be crucial in addressing the human dimension of the crisis.

clueweb22-en0016-82-17265.point_content: Immediate action should include extending social protection, universal health coverage, and income support for those most affected, including informal workers, youth, older workers, migrants, and women.
spans: Immediate and purposeful action to save lives and livelihoods should include extending social protection towards universal health coverage and income support for those most affected. These include workers in the informal economy and in poorly protected and low-paid jobs, including youth, older workers, and migrants. Particular attention must be paid to the situation of women, who are over-represented in low-paid jobs and care roles.

clueweb22-en0016-82-17265.point_content: Support measures include cash transfers, child allowances, healthy school meals, shelter and food relief, employment retention and recovery support, and financial relief for businesses.

clueweb22-en0006-97-10361.point_content: Social distancing means maintaining a distance of at least six feet from others and minimizing contact by avoiding public transportation, limiting nonessential travel, working from home, and skipping social gatherings.
spans: Put simply, the idea is to maintain a distance between you and other people — in this case, at least six feet.

That also means minimizing contact with people. Avoid public transportation whenever possible, limit nonessential travel, work from home and skip social gatherings — and definitely do not go to crowded bars and sporting arenas.

clueweb22-en0006-97-10361.point_content: Social distancing reduces the ability of the virus to spread and has saved thousands of lives in past pandemics.
spans: “Every single reduction in the number of contacts you have per day with relatives, with friends, co-workers, in school will have a significant impact on the ability of the virus to spread in the population,” said Dr. Gerardo Chowell, chair of population health sciences at Georgia State University.
This strategy saved thousands of lives both during the Spanish flu pandemic of 1918 and, more recently, in Mexico City during the 2009 flu pandemic.

clueweb22-en0006-97-10361.point_content: Young people should not continue to socialize as they can spread the virus to vulnerable populations and contribute to overwhelming the health care system.
spans: Please don’t. There is no question that older people and those with underlying health conditions are most vulnerable to the virus, but young people are by no means immune.
Even people who show only mild symptoms may pass the virus to many, many others — particularly in the early course of the infection, before they even realize they are sick.
So you might keep the chain of infection going right to your own older or high-risk relatives.
If you ignore the guidance on social distancing, you will essentially put yourself and everyone else at much higher risk.

clueweb22-en0006-97-10361.point_content: It is okay to leave the house for fresh air, exercise, medicines, or essential resources, but avoid close contact with people and practice hygiene measures.
spans: Absolutely. The experts were unanimous in their answer to this question.
It’s O.K. to go outdoors for fresh air and exercise — to walk your dog, go for a hike or ride your bicycle, for example.
The point is not to remain indoors, but to avoid being in close contact with people.
You may also need to leave the house for medicines or other essential resources.

When you do leave your home, wipe down any surfaces you come into contact with, disinfect your hands with an alcohol-based sanitizer and avoid touching your face. Above all, frequently wash your hands — especially whenever you come in from outside, before you eat or before you’re in contact with the very old or very young.

clueweb22-en0006-97-10361.point_content: Social distancing can cause loneliness which negatively affects health, increasing risks of depression, high blood pressure, heart disease, and weakening the immune system.
spans: A paradox of this moment is that while social distancing is required to contain the spread of the coronavirus, it may also contribute to poor health in the long run.
The Health Resources and Services Administration cautions that loneliness can be as damaging to health as smoking 15 cigarettes a day.
Feelings of isolation and loneliness can increase the likelihood of depression, high blood pressure, and death from heart disease.
They can also affect the immune system’s ability to fight infection — a fact that’s especially relevant during a pandemic.
